item.title: Report E-2025030345
item.description:
Report E-2025030345

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-25
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding a leaking metal drum containing hazardous product, Nitric Acid. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimate 1-pint release onto the wooden trailer floor in a 1’x1’ area as a result of improper packaging. The contractor applied sodium bicarbonate to the release and applied oil dry as well as absorbent pads. The neutralized and impacted absorbents and PPE were containerized into one 55-gallon DF for waste disposal. XPO will manage all waste created from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.description:
Report E-2025030376

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-24
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 24, 2025, four (4) 5-gallon pails of paint were punctured and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained E3 Environmental to remediate the site. The crew collected the damaged pails in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. Absorbents and hand tools were used to remediate the trailer, and all waste was containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-24
  • City: WHITESTOWN
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Operations Supervisor III Keli Linn contacted safety report a Hazardous Spill. Keli stated they were removing a pallet containing UN3378, Sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate, 5.1, PG II, from trailer 552651. Keli stated they noticed that one bag on the side of the pallet was torn and had leaked inside of the plastic wrap. Keli stated she believes the tear in the bag was due to a load shift and the pallet rubbed against the wall of the trailer resulting in an 8-ounce spillage into the plastic wrap, and onto the trailer floor.

  • Description: On March 21, 2025, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN760 had a faulty cap and leaked approximately one (1) cup of product to the trailer floor and drum lid. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Carolina Environmental Response Team, Inc. (CERT) to remediate the site. The crew replaced the damaged cap and utilized neutralizing agent as well as absorbents to collect the released product. All impacted absorbents were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025030259
item.description:
Report E-2025030259

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-20
  • City: ELKTON
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hepaco personnel were dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated two (2) gallons of material released from one (1) box containing two (2) 1-gallon plastic jugs punctured by a forklift. Hepaco personnel observed that the released material impacted 2 ft-by-2 ft area of dock floor concrete. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to neutralize the area and absorb the material containerizing them into one (1) 55-gallon poly drums. The incident generated a total of one (1) container. One (1) 55- gallon poly drum containing empty bottles / neutralized impacted absorbents / Cardboard. All impacted surfaces were confirmed to be neutral, and work was approved. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 19, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1760 was punctured by a nail and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer floor and pavement below. R + L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the site. Crews utilized neutralizers and granular absorbents to the trailer and pavement to absorb the suspected product. All spent materials were collected with hand tools and containerized within one (1) 55-gallon poly drum.

  • Description: AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE KENTUCKY, ONE AIR PACKAGE WAS FOUND LEAKING. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO AEROSOL CANS OF FAT FREE REDDI WHIP, EACH AT 13 OUNCES. BOTH CONTAINERS HAD BROKEN CAPS DUE TO INSUFFICIENT PREPARATION AND PACKAGING FOR TRANSPORTATION. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER PACKAGING. THIS PACKAGE WAS DROPPED OF IN TEXAS USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER XA8359, O-REPS.COM, 41 SEAVIEW CT UNIT 1, PORT TOWNSEND WA 98368-9508.

AFTER REFERRRING TO THE DECISION TREE AND ACTING ACCORDINGLY THE SPILL WAS CLEANED UP AND THE PACKAGE WAS TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP CAGE FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN DISPOSED OF ACCORDING TO THE WASTE DISPOSAL FLOW CHART.

  • Description: On 03/13/2025 at approximately 1800 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 4060191 at the station location in Ronkonkoma, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of 4 fiberboard boxes, each containing multiple bottles of retail cologne and perfume. One bottle from one of the boxes appeared to leak; cause unknown. While including a Shipper's declaration, the package did not appear to have the required markings or labeling attached. The entire shipment was improperly prepared and has been rejected during inspection.

item.title: Report I-2025030038
item.description:
Report I-2025030038

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-13
  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Global Crossing Airlines, Inc
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Global Crossing Airlines, Inc {GCXA} operates freighter services under an ACMI agreement with IBC Airways to Kingston, Jamaica and several cities inside Cuba. As of 02/15/2025, GCXA's Loadmasters; who accompany the aircraft as part of the crew, have detected several instances where Lithium Batteries were found as being undeclared in shipments prior to loading the aircraft. Since 02/15/2025, instructions from the Cargo Operations department of GCXA has been for the Loadmasters to remain vigilant and scrutinize all shipments that may be viewed as suspicious, i.e {labeling, marking on boxes, key words such as "generators" "batteries" etc) prior to loading any ULD's onboard the aircraft. On 03/13/2025, the Loadmasters working the flight scheduled for MIA-CFG-MIA, indicated at 07:08L that again {6th time since 02/15/25), Undeclared hazardous materials were found in the shipment prior to loading and consequently rejected the entire load. The instructions to the ground handler {NAS) was for them to break all the packages since the Loadmasters did not trust any items that were wrapped with black plastic shrink wrap. The Loadmasters reached out for guidance to the Cargo Operations leadership and was advised to stand firm on that decision to reject this shipment. The Loadasters instructed the ground handlers to begin inspecting the completed ULDs and eventually various items ranging from portable electric generators, undeclared car batteries to electric scooters were detected. IBC Airways were informed and eventually they cancelled the flight. The FAA CMT was informed of the events.

item.title: Report X-2025031021
item.description:
Report X-2025031021

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-12
  • City: JNU
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: ALASKA AIRLINES, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Undeclared hazmat found during screening. Other undeclared hazmat found with no release as follows. (Replicating questions 14-29) ALCOHOLS, N.O.S. (ETHANOL)//haz class 3 // UN 1987//not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box//Aerosols, flammable//haz class 2.1 // UN 1950 //not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box// petroleum distillates, N.O.S // haz class 3 // UN 1268 //not shipped as hazardous waste//not toxic by inhalation//not shipped under Exemption, Approval, or CA number//shipment was undeclared with no release//packaging type non-bulk/outer packaging plastic box AWB71913015 arrived from AS66/12. One piece, a blue cooler fell on the ramp and because the lid wasn't taped or anything like that, the lid opened, and its contents were spilled out. It was then that some aerosol cans and a chargeable lithium battery were discovered. The runner brought it over to the warehouse and alerted me to take a look. I was able to pull the contents out of the cooler and found more undeclared DG. There was a tote that was a part of the six lot, so I opened it up to see what was in it and discovered a lot of batteries and lighters. Pictures of everything found and all sides of each piece are attached.

item.title: Report I-2025030044
item.description:
Report I-2025030044

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-03
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: Everts Air Cargo
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 55000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Undeclared hazmat shipment of Lithium Batteries. 5760 used computers from bush Alaska to a re-seller via Anchorage Alaska. Lower Kuskokwim School District (LKSD) engaged with Second Life Mac (SLM)(a company from Skokie, IL) for them to buy their used computers, and provide all services to package and transport them. Because of the very remote location of the computers (Bethel, AK), the LKSD followed SLM's instructions to package and deliver to the airline. SLM instructed LKSD to not mark or label any of the packages, and to cover them under black shrink wrap, deliver to the airline, and the airline agent would take care of everything. Neither the Airline nor Airline Agent knew anything about this shipment. 5 pallets of these items were tendered to the Airline in Bethel, AK, and described by the shipper on our AWB as "ELECTRONICS". Shipper was asked if there were any hazardous materials in the shipment, and shipper answered NO. Shipper signed the Airline's AWB and initialed that there was no hazardous materials in the shipment. 5 pallets were flown from Bethel to Anchorage, AK, consignee notified 3 times without picking the freight up, and after 3 weeks, Airline contacted the Shipper and asked what to do with the shipment? Shipper contacted the Consignee, and they then responded that day, and arrived the next day on sight with marking and labeling to further move these pallets on FedEx. They applied the hazmat dimond label to the 5 pallets while on our ramp. It had rained, and some of the boxes got wet, soaking some contents in water, which initiated a damage freight claim process. No action was taken on the claim, because of two issues: one-freight charges have not been paid for, two-shipment was abandoned for three weeks with no communication from consignee. On March 5th, Airline was notified of a demand letter from a lawyer for a claimed damage amount. The demand letter was elevated to airline administration, and was the first time administration became aware of the hidden hazmat shipment. SLM has a third party involved, Jesse Carnahan with Lynx Enterprises (Wasilla, AK). The Airline does not know how much of or who is responsible for what between Lynx and SLM. Once administration became aware of the non-declared hazmat, an investigation ensued which led to this 5800.1 report. No release or damage to the lithium batteries has been declared.

The released product and damaged can with box will be placed into a 5-gallon metal drum and staged in OS&D. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release. There is no regulatory reporting required for this release.

item.title: Report E-2025030054
item.description:
Report E-2025030054

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-26T21:14:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: WALBRIDGE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 41500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02/26/2025, at 16:34 hours, personnel in the CSXT Yard in Walbridge, OH, discovered UTLX209767, a residue tank car of Ethyl Acrylate, emitting a strong odor. The car was isolated and the shipper, Zeon Chemicals, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2025-02-26-0146). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the car was actively releasing product vapors from the liquid line reducer bushing threads, vapor line reducer bushing threads, and vacuum relief valve (VRV). Contractor personnel applied thread tape and thread dope to secure the liquid line and vapor line bushing releases. Additionally, emergency containment measures were taken to reduce the odor/vapor emissions from the vacuum relief valve. Subsequently, additional contractor personnel were mobilized to safely depressurize the car, remove the faulty VRV, and install a blind flange to ensure the car was leak tight. The issue was identified, and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Sharen Panday (sharen.panday@us.sasol.com). The car was released for transport home shop under shipper OMTA.

X-2025030993 During FRA Hazmat inspection the inspector heard possible hissing from the vacuum relief valve on tank car FURX130488. Inspector notified the RR and contractor determined car had pressure on it and it was coming out of the valve. Contractor replaced the VRV with a steel plug.

  • Description: Overfill company tank at terminal resulting in a spill contained by the dike with ULSD seeping into the gravel lot. Cleanup vendor assessed and confirmed that the containment unit for the UST had been overfilled, and had roughly 3-4 inches of standing diesel in the bottom of the containment unit. Estimated release of 200-300 gallons with the large majority of product confined to the containment unit. Approximately 23 gallons splashed out and reached the ground. CDG managed this spill cleanup and notified NCDEQ.

  • Description: At 2357 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at the terminal BCO. It was reported that a 25-gallon “Octave” UN3264 was released from a 55-gallon DF. The release impacted the trailer floor. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of UN3264 Octave product released to a 15’x8’ area of the trailer floor due to load shifting during transit and puncturing drum. The contactors neutralized the material with sodium bicarbonate and solidifying the release with oil dri. The waste generated was containerized into (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-16
  • City: EIGHTY FOUR
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an area measuring approximately 15ft-by-20ft of the concrete terminal floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due to one (1) 275-gallon poly tote being crushed and punctured by a forklift. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents and used absorbent pads to collect the spent material. The remaining product in the damaged tote was transferred to a new tote. The damaged tote was cut-up and along with the recovered spent absorbents were placed into four (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ETC driver was stopped in turning lane at Buffalo Rd to turn onto 70 HWY when the other party struck us from the passenger side of trailer. Damage for ETC loading heads 1,2,3 and tubes. Landing gear. Operator box. Fender. Right rear tractor tire and rim. Lift gate assembly. Mud flap and bracket. Damage to loading heads resulted in a spill of approximately 15 gallons from the wet lines. CDG was contacted to manage spill cleanup.

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-20
  • City: ELKHART
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SET Environmental personnel were dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated two (2) ounces of material released from one (1) 330-gallon IBC plastic tote due to a loose cap on a faulty lid. SET Environmental personnel observed that the released material impacted the top of the IBC tote. SET Environmental personnel used absorbent pads to wipe down the container and containerized them into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum along with 2 drum liners. The incident generated a total of one (1) waste container. Contractor personnel replaced the lid of the IBC tote. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The waste generated will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: RESPONDED TO AN AIR PACKAGE THAT WAS COLD TO THE TOUCH. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY FIVE POUNDS OF DRY ICE BLOCKS COOLING FOOD. THE PACKAGE ALSO CONTAINS NON-REGULATED ULINE COLD PACKS COOLING THE FOOD. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM PENNSYLVANIA USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER GG8840, THE UPS STORE, 1070 MOUNTAIN LAUREL PLZ, LATROBE PA 15650-5214. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

  • Description: During sort operations at the GEGR location a spill agent was called for a spilled shipment. While repackaging affected shipment they discovered that one shipment contained a plastic bucket with a 5.1 DG placard on it. Printing on the bucket labeled the contents as a UN2880. The outer fiberboard box did not have any DG markings or paperwork required for transit. It was place into a steel salvage package and is being held for the FAA.

UPON INSPECTION OF INNER CONTENTS THERE ARE FORTY-FIVE POWER BANKS, CAPACITY 5000MAH, 3.7V. THEY ARE IMPRINTED POWERFLEX EDF RENEWABLES. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THE PACKAGE WAS SCANNED INTO AN AIR CONTAINER BUT DID NOT MOVE IN THE AIR NETWORK.

item.title: Report E-2025030257
item.description:
Report E-2025030257

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-25T18:19:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-28
  • City: KNOXVILLE
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call Environmental-LTL was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated five to six (5-6) gallons of material released from one (1) 55-gallon plastic drum that was punctured by a forklift. First Call Environmental-LTL personnel observed that the released material impacted 15 ft-by-10 ft of trailer floor and asphalt. First Call Environmental-LTL personnel deployed a neutralizer and granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized them into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The drums also contained PPE, debris, and boom. The punctured drum was placed into a metal drum by the terminal, but due to the corrosive nature First Call Environmental-LTL placed the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon plastic drum. Generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The waste generated will remain onsite for the ESTES team to coordinate disposal

item.description:
Report E-2025030174

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-23T01:09:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-16
  • City: STEWARTVILLE
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed the top of one (1) 330-gallon IBC plastic tote was damaged and approximately twenty (20) ounces of material released impacting the trailer floor. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and placed the spent absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The remaining product was transferred into a new 330-gallon poly tote and shipped onto the consignee. The generated waste was staged onsite for the Dayton Freight Lines team to coordinate disposal.

  • City: MARIETTA

  • Description: On March 19, 2025, one (1) 55-pound bag of UN3378 was torn in transit and released approximately seven (7) pounds of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. HES personnel swept all loose product using hand tools. All released product and damaged bags were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums which were staged onsite.

  • Description: On March 18, 2025, two (2) 50-pound bags of UN3378 were damaged and released approximately four (4) pounds of product to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized hand tools to collect the released product. All spent material and the damaged bags were containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

  • Description: On March 18, 2025, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3267 was damaged and released approximately 20-gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted areas. The crew performed a tote transfer to one (1) new 330-gallon tote. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • City: MONTEBELLO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 17, 2025, one (1) 345-gallon tote of UN1897 had its support leg damaged and released approximately 0.25-gallon of product to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remove the spent product and containerized them in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew also patched the damaged tote and staged it onsite pending a new tote for a transfer.

  • Description: On March 17, one (1) 5-gallon jug of UN1760 was damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Alpha Omega Training and Compliance, Inc. (AOTC) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to clear the site. All impacted materials was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged pail was containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: A few minutes after pushback customers started yelling for help Customer Tamara Jones in 15B stated that her laptop started smoking Customer reported that she was running to her gate when her water bottle spilled in her bag, on to her work computer Customer put the laptop in her seat back pocket and did not tum it on or put it on the charger, she wanted it to dry out When FA Gaston arrived, the laptop was not visibly smoking but stated the area smelt of smoke FA Gaston handled the device with her bare hands and stated that it was warm and getting warmer, but no smoke/sparks FA Gaston placed the device into the TCB Flight returned to the gate where the TCB and the below customer information was handed to the CSR

  • Description: During sort operations at the GEGR location a fiberboard box was discovered with signs of a release. While investigating the shipment it was discovered that the plastic bucket inside was placarded as UN2880 and the removeable lid was damaged causing the release. The outer fiberboard box did not have any DG markings or paperwork required for transport. It was placed into a steel salvage package and is being held for the FAA.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-14
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 14, 2025, eight (8) 5-gallon pails of printing ink were crushed and released approximately one (1) cup of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remove all product. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged pails were containerized in two (2) additional 55-gallon drums.

item.title: Report X-2025030831
item.description:
Report X-2025030831

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-14
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ANCHORAGE, ALASKA, ONE PACKAGE BECAME WET FROM RAINWATER REQUIRING A REWRAP. THE PACKAGE HAD PREVIOUSLY FLOWN FROM ONT TO ANC USING GROUND TO ALASKA RATE SERVICE WHICH MOVES IN THE AIR NETWORK. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED AN INNER BOX MARKED AND LABELED UN1070 NITROUS OXIDE WITH CLASS 2.2 AND 5.1 DIAMOND LABELS. THIS INNER BOX CONTAINED FOUR NITROUS OXIDE CYLINDERS. THERE WERE TWO ADDITIONAL LOOSE NITROUS OXIDE CYLINDERS IN THE BOX ALSO. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM WASHINGTON USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER J21R10, FULFILLMENT CENTER, 11815 TECHNOLOGY LN, FISHERS IN 46038-2890.

  • City: MAPLE GROVE

  • Description: X-2025030923 -HAZMAT CLERK NOTICED AN ODOR COMING FROM THIS PACKAGE WHILE IT SAT ON THE 8 WAY IRREG UNLOAD. IT HAD MINOR LIQUID LEAKS INTERNALLY, NO LIQUID LEAKED BEYOND THE EXTERNAL PACKAGING. X-2025030924-HAZMAT AUDITOR BROUTH THEIR TAM OVER AND SAID ONE OF THE HAZMATS ON THEIR TRAM HAD A STRONG ODOR COMMING FROM IT. INSPECTING THE HAZMAT IT HAD BOTH CLASS 5.1 AND 8 DIAMOND HAZARD LABELS AND INSIDE WERE 4 1GAL CONTAINERS WITH VENTED CAPS. ONE OF THE CAPS HAD BEN SCREWED ON CROOKED WHICH ALLOWED THE INNER CONTENTS TO LEAK OUT.

item.description:
Report E-2025030186

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-13
  • City: CARLISLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1426 ET, Jared Rahn with XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal BCA. It was reported that approximately 55 gallons of UN3066 corrosive unknown trade name released from poly drum due to shifting in transit and lack of dunnage. The release impacted concrete at the terminal yard and inside trailer # 3110507. Contractors report that the damaged drum was overpacked in a 95-gallon poly drum and the impacted absorbents/PPE were containerized in (5) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste will be left onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

While using an electric pallet, the employee elevated the forks and accidentally punctured the drum, causing 2 gallons to spill onto the cement. Veolia personnel immediately responded and mitigated the spill. The punctured drum was overpacked to prevent any further release of material.

The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to collect all spent material in one (1) 5-gallon pail. The damaged pail was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: On March 12, 2025, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN1760 was forked and released approximately twenty-five (25) gallons of product to the trailer interior, dock floor, and pavement below the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew then transferred the product to one (1) new 275-gallon tote for further processing. The damaged tote was broken down and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: Passenger was on inbound flight 38 from HND to LAX when, approximately an hour and a half into the journey, he reported searching for an item in his personal bag. During this process, he noticed that his vape pen was hot to the touch and began Leaking. Mr. Maxine removed the vape from his bag and attempted to place it in the front pocket of the seat ahead. As he did this, he felt the device heat up further and alerted the flight attendant for assistance. The crew responded by properly deploying the TCB bag and disposing of the vape.

  • Description: On 3/8/2025 at approximately 0700 hours, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 5156291 at the hub facility in Indianapolis, reporting a paint spill. The damaged container was placed in a salvage drum and awaits an amended Shipper's Declaration for further transport. the remaining parts of the shipment will continue forward with an Amended Shipper's Declaration.

  • Description: The customer was seated on a Polaris seat(2L) which reclines 180 degree. When he moved his seatback to the upright position, his iPad was stuck in the gap between the seats, which he did not notice. It was folded up from the middle like a taco shell, and the screen glass was broken into pieces. There were no signs of explosion, fire, smoke, heat, swelling, or smell. However, the purser decided to put it into TCB just in case due to the damage caused by the seatback.

  • Description: Carrier picked up the 5 gallon cube from the customer, Hollister Stier, and loaded the waste onto the truck. Driver made other pickups throughout the day. When the driver arrived at the branch, it was discovered that the waste was leaking from the cap and had contaminated another container. In-house spill response team was activated. They were able to clean up the spill and decontaminate the leaking and leaked-on package. Both items were overpacked and shipped to final destination without incident.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1912 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal XCN. It was reported that approximately 100 gallons of "Aluminum Chloride Solution" were released from a plastic tote due to improper loading. The release impacted the inside of trailer #3115138. Per review of photos, this spill also impacted a drain and concrete under the trailer. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 110-gallons of UN2581 Aluminum Chloride Solution product released impacting 1’x40’ drain, 12’x8’ concrete and 5’x12’ trailer floor due to improper loading. The crew recovered the Aluminum Chloride Solution with absorbents and transferred the remaining product into a new tote and cut up damaged tote. The waste consisted of (5) 55-gallon poly totes containing the Aluminum Chloride Solution impacted boom, pads and oil dry, one drum had the impacted cut up tote. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Trained Veolia employees immediately righted the containers and remediated the release of material using absorbent material on top of the spill. The container was uprighted and the lid was re-secured to the package.

item.title: Report E-2025020412
item.description:
Report E-2025020412

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: LOXLEY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated (150) gallons of material released from one (1) 330-gallon plastic tote punctured by a forklift. Clean Harbors personnel observed that the released material impacted 30 ft-by-30 ft area of dock floor concrete. Clean Harbors personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized them into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The remaining material in the product tote was to be transferred to a new 330-gallon IBC tote. However, both pumps cleaned harbors brought were faulty. They had obtained a functional pump from a local supplier and began pumping out the material. Work was paused to obtain upgraded PPE. After obtaining the correct PPE, personnel were able to complete the tote transfer. The incident generated a total of six (6) containers. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum contains two (2) 330-gallon poly tote bladders (cut up), Poly sheeting, and PPE. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum contains a diaphragm pump rinse water. One (1) 330-gallon tote contains the original product. Three (3) 55-gallon poly drums contain absorbent debris. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: One 02/25/2025, at approximately 12:30 hours, an FRA inspector at the CSX Frontier Yard in Buffalo NY, discovered tank car PROX 35916, load of Liquefied Petroleum Gas, was leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Marathon Petroleum Company, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-02-25-00146). EnviroServe, a CSX emergency response contractor, responded and found the cause of the release was the tank car’s liquid line valve was partially open, and secondary closure plug was less than tool tight. Contractor personnel secured the car and verified the release was stopped. The issue identified, and corrective actions, were communicated to the shipper’s representative-John Andersen.

HEPACO, a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found a small drip coming from the bottom outlet area. item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • City: TYRONE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: M. C. TANK TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 46000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: This is a customer unload. After arriving at the plant, the driver sits in his Tractor while the customer unloads the trailer. After the customer hooked up, they began to offload with a 3'' pump. Approximately 1 hour into the unloading cycle, the trailer suffered a vaccum collapse. It was determined that the customer failed to ensure that a ball valve was open on their vapor recovery line. Approximately 2000 gallons of HCL spilled from the bottom of the trailer During the event. All but 100-200 gallons was caught in their containment area. The remaining material left containment and leaked onto a gravel area leading to the unloading area. 1800 gallons inside containment was pumped into totes, and the material that left containment in a gravel area was neutralized and then disposed of by plant personnel. The trailer will be totaled by our insurance company.

  • City: FLETCHER

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: When our driver hooked up to the customer fill line and recognized when that the connection of the adapter fitting didn't feel snug enough (we teach drivers to do the twist test) so he used shims and that helped tigthen up the connection but when he started unloading product began spraying out. By the time he shut down and the pressure relieved 1 gallon was lost amongst his bucket, spill pads and the ground which the customer helped clean up. Additional shims and double gaskets weren't enough to overcome the problem. After going through the troubleshooting we were able to deduce that the camlock arms on the fitting were bad and was going to need to be replaced altogether to make delivery.

  • Description: On February 19, 2025, at 1938 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Ranger personnel in Denison, Texas regarding the release of Sulfuric Acid 50%. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 775 gallons of Sulfuric Acid 50% (UN2796, 8, II) from (3) 330-gallon plastic totes onto asphalt and an adjacent ditch. The release was reportedly due to a rollover accident, impacting multiple areas of asphalt and soil. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The release was neutralized then cleaned with absorbents and the proper PPE. Removal of impacted soil is pending future remediation by contractors. All waste generated from the emergency response portion of addressing this release was containerized in (6) 55-gallon DFs which were taken onsite by contractors pending proper disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1519 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at XNW. It was reported that approximately 1 gallon of Oxonia Active released from 5-gallon poly pail due to improper loading. The release impacted ITSB-0070. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. (Haz Class 5.2) No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallons of UN3109 Oxonia Active product released to an 2’ x3’ area of the trailer floor due to freight not being secured while in transit. The area impacted by oxidizer material was neutralized using Sodium Metabisulfite and areas neutral. The crew used Soda Ash to neutralize the pH. The team observed a pallet with an excavator arm which was also moderately impacted by the spill and neutralized as best as possible. The waste consisted of pails of product was containerized into (1) 55- gallon poly drum, waste product, soda ask, sodium metabisulfite, impacted wood, damaged pail and water was put into (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2025020318
item.description:
Report E-2025020318

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-15
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 15th, 2025, at 18:00 hours, personnel in the CSXT Montgomery, Alabama Yard discovered GATX 53808, a loaded tank car of Terpene Hydrocarbons NOS, leaking from the manway. The car was isolated and the shipper, Kraton Chemicals, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 20250215-00065). Marion Environmental, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the manway cover gasket improperly installed- allowing product to release from the car. Contractor personnel replaced the manway cover gasket and decontaminated the exterior of the car. Following securement of the car it was released for transportation. The issues identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Gerri Sage).

item.title: Report I-2025030028
item.description:
Report I-2025030028

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-22T21:13:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-10
  • City: Calvert
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver went to fill 6,800 gallon tank, and gauge said that it had room for 4,000 gallons. He knew he had just under 4,000 on his truck, but was not going to try to force it in. He stopped to blow out the lines just before the gauge hit 400 gallons left but it started to overflow. He had a loss of containment of about 30 gallons of ferric chloride by the time he blew out his lines. 100% went into containment. When he was done, the tank still read it had 400 gallons until full, indicating that the customer's tank gauge was not working properly. No Exposure Injuries.
